Table 1 Ligand N-H N-Me N-Bn N-Ph O NCN pKa 26.3 24.0 21.0 18.0 7.8 1.5 ΔG(kcal/mol) −14.3 −9.4 −7.9 −7.0 −1.2 5.3 Exploring the conversion mechanism of formaldehyde to CO2 and H2 catalyzed by bifunctional ruthenium catalysts: A DFT study Min Du Jianju Zheng Lan Mei Yuan Zhang Cheng Hou ⁎ School of Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Sciences, State Key Laboratory for Chemistry and Molecular Engineering of Medicinal Resources, Guangxi Normal University, Guilin, 541004, PR China School of Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Sciences State Key Laboratory for Chemistry and Molecular Engineering of Medicinal Resources Guangxi Normal University Guilin 541004 PR China School of Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Sciences, State Key Laboratory for Chemistry and Molecular Engineering of Medicinal Resources, Guangxi Normal University, Guilin, 541004, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Bifunctional catalysts have a wide range of applications in chemical hydrogen storage. However, the versatile structure and complex influencing factors of catalysts still limit the current mechanistic understanding. Herein, a theoretical study based on density functional theory calculation is performed to illuminate the mechanistic preference of the conversion from formaldehyde to CO2 and H2 catalyzed by bifunctional ruthenium catalysts. The computational results indicate: (1) In contrast to the previously proposed mechanism, the catalyst is involved in the formaldehyde hydrolysis reaction and effectively reduces the activation free energy barrier. (2) Metal ligand cooperation mechanism is preferred instead of the metal-centred mechanism due to the stronger interaction between substrate and dual active sites on the bifunctional catalyst. (3) The catalyst with the OH group exhibits better catalytic activity compared with the NH group due to appropriate catalytic driving force, which is governed by the intrinsic electronic effects of the Lewis basic functional ligand. The pKa value can be used as a reliable descriptor to evaluate the catalytic activity of the functional ligand. Our study highlights the advantages of bifunctional catalysts in dehydrogenation-related reactions and proposes feasible strategies for the regulation of bifunctional catalyst activity, which is expected to provide new inspiration for future bifunctional catalyst design. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Homogeneous catalysis Dehydrogenation Bifunctional catalyst Reaction mechanism Density functional theory Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Due to the rapid development of society, the limited fossil fuels are gradually being depleted. Excessive carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion have led to serious challenges such as the greenhouse effect and climate change. There is an urgent need for a paradigm shift in human society to develop renewable, carbon-free/low-carbon energy sources [1–3]. Hydrogen, as a clean and sustainable energy carrier, offers a practical solution for permanent solutions to global energy and environmental problems. With a high thermo-gravimetric density (33.0 kWh/kg), H2 can be efficiently converted into electricity in a fuel cell and the only by-product of its direct combustion is water [4]. Currently, the bottleneck to the utilization of hydrogen energy is the storage process due to its flammable and explosive nature. In response to this issue, chemical hydrogen storage has gained attention as a practical solution. Within a wide range of chemical hydrogen storage systems, the interconversion of carbon dioxide and formic acid is of significant importance both in terms of chemical hydrogen storage and carbon neutralization [5]. Formic acid can be prepared by carbonylation of methanol and subsequent hydrolysis of methyl formate industrially. Its global production capacity is nearly 800,000 t per annum. The dehydrogenation of FA to H2 and CO2 is thermodynamically favourable at room temperature (ΔG° = −32.9 kJ/mol) with a 100% atom efficiency [6]. Furthermore, formaldehyde has received widespread attention due to its ability to produce methanediol after hydrolysis, which has a higher H2 density (8.4 wt%) than formic acid (4.4 wt%). As a result, formaldehyde-H2O system is a more promising candidate for liquid organic hydrogen carrier [7]. The development of homogeneous catalysts for formic acid dehydrogenation can be traced back to the 1960s when Coffey et al. achieved the first formic acid dehydrogenation reaction in a homogeneous environment based on iridium hydride complex and phosphine ligands [8]. Laurenczy and Beller et al. developed a series of catalytic systems for the dehydrogenation of formic acid based on ruthenium and different phosphine ligands and investigated the effect of electronic and steric effects of the ligands on the catalyst activity and stability [9,10]. Himeda et al. prepared an example of a half-sandwich type catalyst to achieve the transfer hydrogenation of ketones using formic acid as a hydrogen source [11]. This work laid the foundation for their subsequent research and the half-sandwich catalyst became the most widely used catalyst for formic acid dehydrogenation to date. Later, the proton responsive site was introduced to the original bipyridine ligand group, which further enhanced the catalytic activity through metal-ligand cooperation [12]. In 2011, Nozaki et al. reported an example of an iridium catalyst based on a pincer ligand, which shows excellent activity [13]. Mechanistic studies suggested that the pincer ligands used would undergo an aromatization/de-aromatization process for the H2 cleavage reaction. This work also initiated the application of pincer-type catalysts to formic acid dehydrogenation reactions [14]. With continued research, base metals exhibit catalytic potential in formic acid dehydrogenation reactions. In 2011, Beller et al. prepared a case of an iron catalyst with a conversion frequency TOF of up to 1000 h−1 in situ, with catalytic activity comparable to that of noble metal catalysts [15]. Kinetic studies and density functional theory calculations reveal that the rate-determining step in its catalytic cycle is the carbon dioxide dissociation process. Guided by these excellent pioneering works (Fig. 1 a), current research is mainly concerned with the design of auxiliary ligands and the expansion of metal centres [16–23]. In particular, the emergence of dinuclear formic acid dehydrogenation catalysts has offered new ideas for future catalyst design [24–27]. Meanwhile, computational chemistry, an indispensable tool for understanding reaction mechanisms, offers valuable insight into the rational design of catalysts. In 2014, an investigation of the methanol dehydrogenation reaction of Ru pincer complexes by Yang et al. reveals that the catalytic cycle consists of three independent stages, methanol dehydrogenation, formic acid formation and formic acid dehydrogenation [28]. A self-promoted mechanism was proposed, in which methanol and water are involved in the proton transfer process instead of the proton of the NH group. Hall et al. explored an example of a Ru-catalyzed methanol dehydrogenation reaction and found that the functional ligand dominated the catalytic cycle with the metal centre merely acting as a spectator [29]. Kozuch et al. performed a computational study on the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction mediated by different ruthenium active species [30]. Applying the energetic span model, the concentration effect of the reactants was considered. It was found that the dihydride Ru complex was the most plausible active species and the experimental mass spectrum observation was rationalized. Based on theoretical calculations, Jaccob et al. presented theoretical studies on the mechanism of formic acid dehydrogenation catalysed by a series of half-sandwich complexes with proton-responsive ligands [31,32]. It is revealed that β-H elimination is the rate-determining step in these catalysts and H3O+ plays an important role in the protonation of hydride. These important theoretical findings demonstrate the mechanistic diversity and complexity of the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction. Recently, Singh et al. synthesized a series of highly stable water-soluble Ru complexes (Fig. 1b and c) using non-phosphine ligands [33]. Efficient catalytic dehydrogenation of formic acid and formaldehyde is released in water at 90 °C under base-free conditions, which is milder compared with many efficient dehydrogenation catalysts [34–36]. Meanwhile, it was observed that different functional ligands cause large discrepancies in activity. These intriguing findings have raised our curiosity regarding the variety of reaction pathways due to the appearance of functional ligands. Moreover, the previous study suggested that the catalyst with a similar structure can proceed with the metal-centred mechanism via the hemilabile behaviour of the functional ligand [37]. Which mechanism is preferred by the catalyst at different stages of the catalytic cycle? Why do functional ligands with similar structures exhibit significant differences in activity? Which step is the rate-determining step of the whole catalytic cycle? To answer these questions, a comprehensive exploration of the possible reaction pathways of hydrolysis and dehydrogenation of formaldehyde catalyzed by bifunctional ruthenium catalysts based on density functional theory (DFT). With the aid of computational chemistry, it is expected to illuminate the details of the catalytic process and the origin of the differences in reaction activity to offer beneficial advice for rational catalyst design. 2 Computational details All the DFT calculations were carried out using the Gaussian 16 A.03 program [38]. To choose the most appropriate functional for the calculation, a series of density functional methods widely used in the relevant computational studies, including B3LYP [39], B3PW91 [40], M06 [41] and ωB97XD [42], were compared. The results of activation free energy barrier are generally consistent using different functionals (Table S1). Therefore, M06-L [43] functional was chosen for this study considering the computational expense and accuracy. The geometry optimisation and the search for transition states were performed at the theoretical level of M06-L/def2-SVP [44]. Frequency calculations are used to confirm the existence of local minima (no imaginary frequencies) and transition states (only one imaginary frequency). All transition states were verified by intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations. To further improve the energy results, single point energy calculations were performed on the optimised structure using the SMD continuous solvent model (H2O) at the M06-L/def2-TZVP theoretical level [45]. A 1.89 kcal/mol correction was added to all species to account for the change of state from 24.45 to 1 L/mol. The standard free energy corrections are applied. The natural bond orbital analysis was performed using NBO version 3.1 as implemented in Gaussian 16 package [46]. All calculated 3D structures were rendered using IboView software [47] and the natural bond orbitals were depicted by IQmol software [48]. The Cartesian coordinates of the optimised structure and the corresponding energy results of the DFT calculation are provided in the support information. 3 Results and discussion To illuminate the reaction mechanism and reveal the origin of the different catalytic activity between Cat.1 and Cat.2, a comparison of possible pathways was explored in detail. Two main types of mechanisms are considered, including the metal-centred (MC) mechanism and the metal-ligand cooperation (MLC) mechanism. In the MC mechanism, NH and OH functional groups behave as a hemilabile ligand to provide the vacant site for reactants coordination. In the MLC mechanism, NH and OH functional groups are involved in the proton transfer process. The catalytic cycle consists of three stages: (1) the reaction of formaldehyde with water to form methylene glycol; (2) the dehydrogenation of the methylene glycol to produce hydrogen and formic acid; (3) the dehydrogenation of formic acid to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide. For the nomenclature of the calculated structures, the intermediate in the catalytic process is denoted by 'IM' and the transition state in the catalytic process is denoted by 'TS'. For catalysts with different functional groups, the ligand 'L' is denoted as 'O' or 'N' as a subscript. Metal-Centered (MC) Mechanism. The calculated potential energy surface of the MC mechanism is shown in Fig. 2 along with the reaction pathways. The catalyst precursor is coordinated with water to form MC0 after the dissociation of HCl. Then, the generation of MC1 occurs via the transition state TSpre, which is the starting point of the MC mechanism. The activation free energy barrier for the pre-activation is 9.3 and 9.9 kcal/mol for Cat.1 and Cat.2, respectively. Subsequently, the functional ligand dissociates to provide a vacant site and formaldehyde coordinates to the Ru centre and undergoes an insertion reaction via transition state TS1 to produce intermediate IM2. During this process, Cat.1 has a lower energy barrier (TS1O: ΔG≠ = 11.6 kcal/mol) than Cat.2 (TS1N: ΔG≠ = 15.6 kcal/mol) . Afterwards, IM2 isomerises to form the vacant site and undergoes a β-H elimination reaction via TS2 to produce the formic acid and the metal hydride intermediate IM3. The difference in activation free energy barriers between Cat.1 and Cat.2 is not significant in this process (TS2O: ΔG≠ = 27.1 kcal/mol, TS2N: ΔG≠ = 27.3 kcal/mol). Next, formic acid coordinates to the Ru centre to produce H2 via TS3 to give the stable intermediate IM4. For this process, the energy barriers of the two catalysts are similar (TS3O: ΔG≠ = 22.0 kcal/mol, TS3N: ΔG≠ = 22.2 kcal/mol). The following β-H elimination reaction TS4 produces CO2 and the metal hydride intermediate IM3. Finally, the water molecule coordinates to the Ru centre and undergoes a coupling with the hydride complex to release H2 via TS5 and MC1 is regenerated. The calculations indicate that in the MC mechanism, the formate complex IM4 becomes a thermodynamic sink on the potential energy surface. For the catalyst Cat. 2, the rate-determining step is the H2 release with an energy barrier of 45.0 kcal/mol (IM4N →TS5N), while for the catalyst Cat. 1, the rate-determining step has an energy barrier of 31.4 kcal/mol (IM4O→TS5O). The high activation free energy barrier of the metal-centred mechanism suggests that the pathway is less plausible. MLC Mechanism. As for the MLC mechanism, the mechanistic selectivity will be discussed in terms of the three stages of the reaction. In the first stage, formaldehyde undergoes a hydrolysis reaction to form methylene glycol. In the second stage, methylene glycol is dehydrogenated to formic acid and H2. In the third stage, formic acid produces CO2 and H2 through further dehydrogenation. Stage I. The calculated potential energy surface of Stage I is shown in Fig. 3 along with different reaction pathways. For the MLC mechanism, two main possible pathways are considered. In pathway 1, water coordinated to the Ru centre, followed by ligand-assisted OH cleavage to produce the intermediate MC1 via TS6. Subsequently, the coordinated hydroxyl group is transferred to the carbon atom of carbonyl and the active ligand transfers the proton to the oxygen atom of carbonyl via TS7 to generate methylene glycol. In pathway 2, formaldehyde is firstly coordinated to the metal centre and the water molecule attacks the carbonyl carbon TS8 through the outer sphere with the assistance of the ligand. Subsequently, the functional ligand transfers the proton to the alkoxide IM2 via the transition state TS9 to generate methylene glycol. For Stage I, Cat.1 prefers the second reaction pathway. The activation free energy barrier outer-sphere coupling reaction via TS8O is 8.1 kcal/mol and the followed proton transfer via TS9O is uphill by 4.3 kcal/mol. In contrast, Cat.2 prefers reaction pathway 1. The activation free energy barrier of OH cleavage via TS6N is 9.8 kcal/mol. The subsequent concerted transfer via TS7N is uphill by 8.9 kcal/mol. Therefore, Cat.1 exhibits better catalytic activity compared with Cat.2 in the formaldehyde hydrolysis reaction. Moreover, the formaldehyde hydrolysis reaction without the participation of a catalyst is investigated as well (Figure S1). The activation barrier of the four-member ring transition state and the proton-shuttle type six-member ring transition state is 37.8 and 24.9 kcal/mol, respectively. Therefore, the involvement of a catalyst can significantly lower the free energy barrier and facilitate the formaldehyde hydrolysis reaction. Stage II. The calculated potential energy surface of Stage II is shown in Fig. 4 along with the possible reaction pathways In the second stage, the methylene glycol undergoes dehydrogenation to formic acid. Two reaction pathways are considered, the formic acid is generated from the methylene glycol either via a concerted bifunctional hydrogen transfer (TS10) or via a β-H elimination mechanism TS2 after the OH bond cleavage via TS9. The calculations indicated that the bifunctional dehydrogenation mechanism via TS10O was preferred for the catalyst with an energy barrier of 13.1 kcal/mol. Despite the low energy barrier for OH bond cleavage via TS9O, the transition state energy barrier for inner β-H elimination via TS2O is found to be as high as 27.9 kcal/mol, which is kinetically unfavourable. The H2 is released via TS11O with the activation free energy barrier of 10.8 kcal/mol. For the catalyst Cat.2, the free energy barrier for bifunctional transfer via TS10N is lower compared with the OH bond cleavage process via TS9N. Therefore, Cat.2 prefers the bifunctional hydrogen transfer (ΔG≠ = 7.0 kcal/mol) as well. The generated Ru hydride complex IM3N is relatively more stable than Cat.1 (ΔG = −13.0 kcal/mol). Then, the subsequent H2 is generated with the aid of formic acid via the proton-shuttle transition state TS11N with an activation energy barrier of 16.5 kcal/mol. The proton-shuttle H2 mechanism via different proton sources was probed and the transition state with formic acid is the lowest in activation free energy (Figure S2). The calculated results of this stage indicate Cat.1 has a lower activation energy barrier than Cat.2. The difference in thermodynamic stability of important intermediates such as metal hydride and alkoxide is the origin of the difference in energy barriers. Stage III. The calculated potential energy surface of Stage III is shown in Fig. 5 along with the intermediates and transition states. In the third stage, formic acid undergoes a bifunctional dehydrogenation reaction to yield CO2 and H2. Similar to the second stage, the dehydrogenation process can occur either via a bifunctional hydrogen transfer mechanism (pathway 1) or via the OH cleavage followed by a β-H elimination reaction (pathway 2). The H2 is generated via a proton shuttle mechanism assisted by formic acid. After hydrogen release, the catalyst is regenerated and the catalytic cycle restarts. For Cat.1, the calculations suggest that the bifunctional hydrogen transfer via TS12O has a higher energy barrier compared to OH bond cleavage TS13O. However, the formate coordinated complex IM4O becomes a thermodynamic sink on the potential energy surface after TS13O. The subsequent β-H elimination transition state occurs via TS4O with the free activation energy barrier of 25.4 kcal/mol. Thus, intermediate IM4O returns to MLC1O via TS13O and then generates IM3O via the bifunctional hydrogen transfer transition state TS12O with an activation free energy barrier of 14.3 kcal/mol (IM4O→TS12O). The subsequent hydrogen release process has an energy barrier of 14.1 kcal/mol (IM4O→TS11O). Therefore, the formic acid dehydrogenation process is the rate-determining step, which is consistent with the kinetic experimental results. However, the activation free energy of OH bond cleavage via TS13N is 11.1 kcal/mol, which is less favourable than TS12N . Therefore, Cat.2 undergoes bifunctional hydrogen transfer with the activation free energy of 7.7 kcal/mol. The generated hydride complex IM3N is the rate-determining step for Stage III with the relatively higher energy barrier of 16.5 kcal/mol for H2 release via TS11N. The total potential energy surface of the three stages combined is depicted in the support material (Figure S3). The rate-determining step (RDS) was determined by applying the energy span model. The energy barriers for Cat.1 and Cat.2 are 14.8 and 21.3 kcal/mol, respectively. Therefore, Cat.1 should have better catalytic activity, which is consistent with the experimental results. The importance of catalyst involvement in methylene glycol production. The calculated results suggest that the catalyst is involved in the formation of methylene glycol which effectively lowers the energy barrier compared to the formaldehyde hydrolysis process without the catalyst. To gain a deeper insight into the reasons underlying this result, NBO analysis is performed to investigate the donor-acceptor interactions between the reactants and the catalyst. The reactant adduct of TS8O was chosen to calculate the second-order perturbation energy (E(2)) of corresponding orbitals (Fig. 6 ). For the reactants adduct with the bifunctional catalyst Cat.1, the E(2) energy of oxygen lone pair of the water molecule and d orbital of Ru centre to the πC = O* antibonding orbital is 10.6 and 1.8 kcal/mol, respectively. As for the reactants without the catalyst, the E(2) energy of oxygen lone pair of the water molecule and σ orbital of a water molecule to the πC = O* antibonding orbital is 5.5 and 0.2 kcal/mol, respectively. Both the metal centre and the alkoxide ligand effectively activate the substrate via these stronger orbital interactions, increasing the electrophilicity of the aldehyde along with the nucleophilicity of the water molecule, which leads to a lower energy barrier for the formaldehyde hydrolysis reaction. The origin of mechanistic preference. Concerning the mechanistic selectivity, the MLC mechanism is significantly more favourable than the MC mechanism. The energy decomposition analysis based on the distortion-interaction model [49] was carried out to shed light on the mechanistic preference (Fig. 7 ). The calculated results suggest that the MLC mechanism provides greater interaction energy (ΔEint = −21.6 kcal/mol) due to the dual-active sites both participate in the bond breaking and formation process, which is approximately three times greater than the interaction energy of the MC mechanism (ΔEint = −6.2 kcal/mol). In addition, distinct from the typical pincer-type ligand, Cat.1 lacks strong trans-effects to induce ligand dissociation. Therefore, an extra energy penalty is required for Cat.1 to behave as a hemilabile ligand in the MC mechanism. With this understanding in mind, it was envisaged that ligand dissociation may be facilitated by increasing the length of the carbon chain linked to the pyridine ligand. The calculated results (Fig. 8 ) suggest that the free energy required for dissociation is 6.4 kcal/mol and the reaction activation energy is 11.0 kcal/mol when the two methylene groups were linked to the pyridine ligand. However, a significant change in reaction free change was observed when three methylene groups were linked to the pyridine ligand. The reaction free energy for ligand dissociation is −3.5 kcal/mol, suggesting that the OH functional ligand prefers to remain dissociated. Moreover, the activation free energy barrier of formaldehyde hydrolysis is only 4.8 kcal/mol, which implies that increasing the carbon chain length of the pyridine ligand is a viable strategy for achieving the hemilabile mechanism. The origin of the different activity between O H vs N H functional groups. Numerous bifunctional catalysts employ an amide group as a proton acceptor. However, it was found that Cat.2 with the NH group have a higher activation energy barrier, which is consistent with the observed lower turnover frequency. As shown in the calculated potential energy surface (Figure S3), the formation of metal hydride is an exothermic process, forming a thermodynamic sink on the PES (ΔG = −15.9 kcal/mol), resulting in a high energy barrier for the subsequent H2 release process. In contrast, for Cat.1 with alkoxide as a proton acceptor, the reaction free energy of the formic acid dehydrogenation is only −1.2 kcal/mol, providing the appropriate driving force in this system. The reason behind these results arises from the intrinsic difference between the two ligands’ electronic effects. The OH group is more acidic than the NH group. Therefore, the amide group is more basic compared with alkoxide and thus can provide a stronger driving force for the dehydrogenation reaction. Nevertheless, excessive driving force inhibits the catalytic activity in the subsequent catalytic stage, resulting in a lower turnover frequency. To validate our assumptions, a series of catalysts with substituted amine groups were designed at the theoretical level (Fig. 9 ). The pKa of the functional groups and the reaction free energy in the catalytic formic acid dehydrogenation reaction were calculated (Table 1 ), which displayed a strong linear correlation. The theoretical pKa value of 7.8 and 26.3 for Cat.1 and Cat.2, respectively, which is in line with the reaction free energy, −1.2 and −14.3 kcal/mol, respectively. For the N-Me and N-Bn substituted functional ligand, weaker basicity compared with the NH group is observed even though being a secondary amine. The explanation for the calculated results is that the methyl and benzyl groups repel with the p-cymene ligand when the amide group accepts a proton. Thus, the steric effect weakens the basicity of the amide group. For the phenyl-substituted amide group, the conjugation effect disperses the electron density of the amide lone pair, which further diminishes the basicity and leads to an increased reaction free energy. As an extreme case, the strong electron-withdrawing effect of the cyano-substituted group causes the amide group to exhibit weak basicity, resulting in positive reaction free energy of the formic acid dehydrogenation reaction, which is thermodynamically less favourable. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have performed a mechanistic study on the hydrolysis and dehydrogenation of formaldehyde catalysed by ruthenium bifunctional catalysts. The computational results suggest that: (1) bifunctional ruthenium catalysts can produce effective orbital interactions between substrates and dual active sites of bifunctional catalyst, thereby effectively activating the formaldehyde and reducing the activation energy barrier; (2) the MLC mechanism is more favourable than the MC mechanism in the different catalytic stage. The MC mechanism possesses a high energy barrier due to overcoming the deformation of ligand dissociation. Increasing the carbon chain length of the functional ligand can compensate for the lack of trans-effect and promote ligand hemilability; (3) the intrinsic differences in the functional ligands’ electronic effect of Cat.1 and Cat.2 bring about the divergent catalytic activity. Nevertheless, over-stabilised intermediates caused by the excessive driving force may inhibit catalytic activity. The pKa value of the NH or OH group in a bifunctional catalyst can be used as a reliable descriptor to evaluate the MLC driving force. Our study demonstrates the advantages of bifunctional catalysts in dehydrogenation reactions and proposes new strategies for regulating and evaluating the catalytic driving force. These theoretical findings are expected to provide valuable information for the rational design of novel catalysts for chemical hydrogen storage applications in the future. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional catalysts have a wide range of applications in chemical hydrogen storage. However, the versatile structure and complex influencing factors of catalysts still limit the current mechanistic understanding. Herein, a theoretical study based on density functional theory calculation is performed to illuminate the mechanistic preference of the conversion from formaldehyde to CO2 and H2 catalyzed by bifunctional ruthenium catalysts. The computational results indicate: (1) In contrast to the previously proposed mechanism, the catalyst is involved in the formaldehyde hydrolysis reaction and effectively reduces the activation free energy barrier. (2) Metal ligand cooperation mechanism is preferred instead of the metal-centred mechanism due to the stronger interaction between substrate and dual active sites on the bifunctional catalyst. (3) The catalyst with the OH group exhibits better catalytic activity compared with the NH group due to appropriate catalytic driving force, which is governed by the intrinsic electronic effects of the Lewis basic functional ligand. The pKa value can be used as a reliable descriptor to evaluate the catalytic activity of the functional ligand. Our study highlights the advantages of bifunctional catalysts in dehydrogenation-related reactions and proposes feasible strategies for the regulation of bifunctional catalyst activity, which is expected to provide new inspiration for future bifunctional catalyst design.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring the conversion mechanism of formaldehyde to CO2 and H2 catalyzed by bifunctional ruthenium catalysts: A DFT study
